title: 114_s3103
content: The Fort Sumter National Monument in South Carolina was established to commemorate historic events, including the first engagement of the Civil War in 1861. Fort Moultrie, where the British were defeated in 1776, was acquired by the Federal Government in 1960. Since then, it has been administered by the National Park Service without a clear management mandate. Fort Sumter and Fort Moultrie were important in protecting Charleston Harbor and the US coastal defense system. Fort Moultrie is the only National Park site preserving coastal defense history from 1776 to 1947. Sullivan's Island Life Saving Station, built in 1896, is listed on the National Register of Historic Places. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, the term "map" refers to the Boundary Map for Fort Sumter and Fort Moultrie National Historical Park. The term "Park" means the Fort Sumter and Fort Moultrie National Park. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The term "State" means the State of South Carolina. The term "Sullivan's Island Life Saving Station Historic District" includes specific structures and land between Sullivan's Island Life Saving Station and the mean low water mark. SEC. 4. FORT SUMTER AND FORT MOULTRIE NATIONAL PARK. Establishment of Fort Sumter and Fort Moultrie National Park in South Carolina to preserve historical values and cultural resources. The boundary includes land, water, and submerged land depicted on a map available for public inspection. The Secretary administers the Park in accordance with the Act and applicable laws. The Secretary administers Fort Sumter and Fort Moultrie National Park in South Carolina in accordance with applicable laws, including the interpretation of historical events such as the Battle of Sullivan's Island in 1776 and the Civil War. The development of the coastal defense system of the United States from the Revolutionary War to World War II includes events related to Fort Sumter and Fort Moultrie, the Sullivan's Island Life Saving Station, the associated lighthouse, and coastal defense sites built during the Endicott Period. The Secretary may enter into cooperative agreements with entities and individuals to carry out the Act, which focuses on the lives of workers, soldiers, prisoners, and captive Africans associated with Fort Sumter and Fort Moultrie. SEC. 5. REPEAL OF EXISTING LAW. Section 2 of the Joint Resolution establishing the Fort Sumter National Monument in South Carolina is repealed.
